author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Your `new package` pull request met all of the guidelines for auto-merging and is scheduled to be merged when the mandatory waiting period (3 days) has elapsed.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have read the package naming guidelines: https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/dev/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines-1



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment. You can edit blocking comments, adding `[noblock]` to them in order to unblock auto-merging.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->

Le Wed, Sep 27, 2023 at 02:34:46PM -0700, Michael Goerz a écrit :
> Wouldn’t `SignedPerms` be a better name?

Well,  SPerm is the type defined in the package. This leaves SignedPerms as
an available name. But if this comment is blocking I can change the name...
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Jean MICHEL, Groupes et representations, IMJ-PRG UMR7586 tel.(33)157279144
Bureau 639 Bat. Sophie Germain Case 7012 - 75205 PARIS Cedex 13
[noblock] I can unblock it, it just seemed like `SPerms` wasn't very descriptive… Maybe let's see if we can get a second opinion.
I agree that SignedPerms is a better and more descriptive name.
Also note that `SPerm` is a dictionary word that may not relate to the package. [noblock]

Since I do not enjoy that my package is blocked I will submit it again today under the name `SignedPerms`. But note that your criticisms are not very consistent. You accept abbreviating Permutations as `Perms` (presumably since julia does it already with `sortperm`) but you do not accept abbreviating `Sign`as `S`.  But the naming scheme of julia is already full of such inconsistencies.

Abbreviations aren't a problem! The issue is with non-descriptive or ambiguous names. As you note, "perm" for "permutation" is pretty easily understood, with a little context. `SPerms` might just as well be `SortedPerms` or `SpecialPerms`, or many other things.

There's no claim of consistency across the ecosystem. Plenty of "bad" package names have slipped through, which should not be taken as an excuse for future package names. Moreover, opinions can differ on what makes a good package name. For example, I'm not quite as opposed to acronyms as some others. Even the official guidelines have evolved over time.

Don't take these comments as a criticism: this is just community feedback to help you find a better package name. At least in my opinion, in most cases the package author should have the last word on naming. So, if you insist on the name, I would unblock my comment. But I think you're much better off renaming to `SignedPerms`: hopefully you agree that it's a significantly better package name.
OK. I submitted SignedPerms. You can close the pull request
This PR will automatically close after 30 days of inactivity
